title: 115_hr479
content: The Act titled "North Korea State Sponsor of Terrorism Designation Act of 2017" requires a report on designating the government of North Korea as a state sponsor of terrorism. Congress found that North Korea was designated as a state sponsor of terrorism in 1988, but the designation was rescinded in 2008 due to commitments to dismantle its nuclear weapons program. However, North Korea has not upheld these commitments, posing a growing threat according to US officials. The U.S. Department of State considers weapons transfers violating nonproliferation regimes as a factor for designation as a state sponsor of terrorism. North Korea has harbored members of the Japanese Red Army since a 1970 hijacking. In a 2010 court case, it was found that North Korea provided material support to the Japanese Red Army. In support of terrorist activities, North Korea provided material support to designated foreign terrorist organizations like the Japanese Red Army and Hezbollah. This included involvement in attacks such as the 1972 Lod Airport attack in Israel and the 2006 attacks against Israel by Hezbollah. Additionally, North Korean officials were found guilty of attempting to assassinate a North Korean dissident in exile in 2010. The Reconnaissance General Bureau was sentenced to 10 years in prison. South Korea and the FBI concluded that North Korea was responsible for cyber attacks on nuclear power plants and Sony Pictures Entertainment. The attacks were described as acts of cyber-terror. Malaysian authorities allege North Korea's involvement in the poisoning of Kim Jong-nam with VX nerve agent in Kuala Lumpur. Congress believes North Korea meets criteria for state sponsor of terrorism. Secretary of State to determine designation within 90 days. Within 90 days of the Act's enactment, the Secretary of State will determine if North Korea meets the criteria for being designated as a state sponsor of terrorism. The determination will be submitted in unclassified form, with the possibility of a classified annex. SEC. 3. DEFINITIONS. In this Act, "appropriate congressional committees" refer to the Senate's Committee on Foreign Relations and the House of Representatives' Committee on Foreign Affairs. "North Korea" is defined as the Government of the Democratic People's Republic of Korea. "State sponsor of terrorism" refers to a country determined by the Secretary of State for specific purposes under various acts. The government mentioned in (22 U.S.C. 2371) or section 40 of the Arms Export Control Act (22 U.S.C. 2780) is subject to specific provisions of law. The curr_chunk states that support for acts of international terrorism has been repeatedly provided and was passed by the House of Representatives on April 3, 2017.
